history.content:
I took your current schedule more or less (two breadths instead of one) this past fall. Personally I found ee16a to be more time-consuming and more conceptually involved than 61a, but I also thought 16a had noticeably easier exams. It's hard to say which class is harder grade-wise, since 16a never releases averages or final grading bins.

I think what helped me do well in the class was doing the homework meticulously and mostly by myself. The homeworks were definitely harder than the exams, and if you work your way through them I think you'll be in pretty good shape. The homework also often introduced new concepts (or new applications of concepts), and these were on some of the exams.

I didn't use any outside resources, so I can't really speak to how useful those are. Doing a few practice exams before midterms and the final also helped.

Good luck!

EDIT: IMO, CS61a is definitely harder (both difficulty wise and grade wise if you're shooting for a very high grade) than ee16a. EE16a is more basic and doesn't get too complex, whereas 61a takes some simple topics and really makes them difficult for the purpose of exams.

Personally I found ee16a to be more time-consuming and more conceptually involved than 61a, but I also thought 16a had noticeably easier exams. It's hard to say which class is harder grade-wise, since 16a never releases averages or final grading bins.

I think what helped me do well in the class was doing the homework meticulously and mostly by myself. Good luck!

children.subject:
Tips:
1. Find a good homework/study group!! I can't repeat how important this is, I found EE16A/EE16B manageable and fun because of my group.

2. Make sure to understand the techniques taught in the class, and be able to use them without errors (and ideally do them fast without errors). Many homework/test problems in the class rely on a underlying set of mechanical techniques (e.g. Guassian elimination, solving for eigenvalue/eigenvectors, nodal analysis, etc). The most common problem I've seen as a student and as a TA are people misusing the techniques or making accidental arithmetic errors.

3. Ask questions! In lecture, in discussion, and office hours. Concepts can be confusing and the best way to clarify them is to ask questions when the arise. Lecture notes, class notes, and discussion solutions are your friend as well. Outside resources are iffy (sometimes they cover too much/too little and notation can be inconsistent with the class), so use them with caution (note, I do not think they are necessary to do well in the class).

4. Practice, practice, practice. (Why? See point 2.) But remember to practice smart. I've seen a few students who have practiced a lot but repeat the same mistake throughout. When practicing make sure to take systematic breaks to understand the mistakes you are making and how to fix them.

Hope these help!

history.content:
Hey guys! hope everyone's having a great break.

I'll be taking EE16A with CS61A and one breadth next semester. I have no prior experience to linear algebra or circuiting so this will be my first exposure to these topics.

So far, I've read the official fall 2018 Notes up until the first midterm, and have done the practice problems at the end of each note to prepare. I've also watched 3brown1blue linear algebra videos on YT (is this even effective? I heard it was on FB).

Anyways, does anyone have any tips for succeeding in this class? Any essential knowledge you wish you would have known going into EE16A? Advice on what kind of time commitment/workload/difficulty is involved with this class would be great as well, since I don't really have a scope of how hard EE16A will be.

Thanks so much for any insights or advice, it truly means a lot to me .

tldr: share ee16a experiences/tips pls
history.subject: Tips for succeeding in EE16A ?
